webTitle: George Osborne staked his reputation on deficit control yet problems spiral

fields.bodyText: For George Osborne, the latest grim public finance figures will have made depressing reading. The chancellor has staked his entire reputation – and the future of the economy – on bringing Britain's deep deficit under control. Repair the Treasury's coffers, the coalition's argument goes, and you win back the confidence of financial markets – and, along the way, tame the overweening state and create room for businesses to flourish. But Tuesday's figures from the Office for National Statistics showed that net borrowing, excluding financial help to Britain's banks, stood at almost £18bn in May – up from just over £15bn in the same month in 2011. Analysts queued up to warn that they cast doubt on the Office for Budget Responsibility's forecasts for tax and spending. It seems that far from the Tories' policies taming the deficit, it's getting worse: the economy has slipped into a double-dip recession, pushing up public spending on benefits and tax credits, and depressing tax revenues as firms suffer. The great debate that will now rage is about cause and effect: has the rapid pace of the coalition's spending cuts and tax rises helped to tip the UK into recession, as Ed Balls has consistently argued, exacerbating the deficit and making Osborne's policies self-defeating in their own terms? Or has an unforeseeable financial car crash on the continent brought the recovery to a shuddering halt, through no fault of the chancellor's? Certainly, the timing looks fishy for Osborne: the first quarter of negative growth in the UK was last autumn, before the latest bout of euro-neurosis hit. But as the political recriminations about the causes of the double dip keep flying, the chancellor will face some immediate, practical decisions about how to respond. He has already been forced to announce plans to extend his austerity policies for two years beyond the next general election, after the finances deteriorated as a result of the slowdown, and David Cameron's rhetoric about welfare cuts this week underlines the fact that the Conservatives are serious about slicing into the state. But you can only pull that trick once, and Tuesday's figures suggest the chancellor could be left with a stark choice by the time of his autumn statement in four or five months' time: cut even deeper than his current radical plans envisage – or accept that he cannot meet his target of eliminating the structural deficit over five years. Of course, Osborne will fear the wrath of the markets if he deviates from the course of fiscal righteousness he's laid down and he has so far refused any opportunity to soften his approach. But the response of ratings agencies and bond investors to the deteriorating outlook in many eurozone countries in recent months shows that they're not just interested in what governments promise – but also in whether severe economic weakness makes their plans impossible to deliver. The latest radical policies from the Treasury and the Bank, effectively reopening the emergency special liquidity scheme for banks, and promising a flood of cheap money under the "funding for lending scheme", show just how serious the economic situation has already become. Osborne should swallow his pride, bow to the inevitable and accept that sticking to his targets in the face of recession and financial turmoil would be the height of fiscal irresponsibility.

webTitle: UK economic outlook getting worse, warns Bank of England

fields.standfirst: Mervyn King says he is more 'pessimistic' about the eurozone and its effect on the British economy than he was in May
fields.body:
A sharp deterioration in the outlook for the global economy over the last six weeks provoked Bank of England governor Mervyn King to back an extra £50bn of quantitative easing, MPs heard on Tuesday, adding to the gloom surrounding the UK's prospects for recovery.

King said the spillover effects of the eurozone crisis in Asia and the US had forced him to rethink his view on the financial crisis and vote for more QE.

"What has particularly concerned me in the last several months – why I have voted for more easing policy – was my concern about the worsening I see in the position in Asia and other emerging markets," King said.

"And my colleagues in the United States are more concerned than they were at the beginning of the year about what is happening to the American economy," he added.

The world was not half-way through a deep crisis and the eurozone turmoil was creating enormous uncertainty, leaving Britain at risk of a downward spiral if businesses postponed investment, he told the all-party Treasury select committee.

Britain's economy slipped into its second recession since the start of the financial crisis around the turn of the year and fears of a longer slump have been rising as companies hold back investment and exports suffer from the eurozone crisis.

"We are in the middle of a deep crisis, with enormous challenges to put our own banking system right and challenges for the rest of the world that they are struggling with," King the committee.

"In the last six weeks … I am very struck by how much has changed since we produced our May Inflation Report," King said.

"I am pessimistic [about the eurozone outlook]. I am particularly concerned because over two years now we have seen the situation in the euro area get worse and the problem being pushed down the road," he said.

The central bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) voted 5-4 against increasing the current £325bn of QE at its last meeting.

King joined external members David Miles and Adam Posen and Bank of England colleague Paul Fisher in voting for more QE, but was outvoted by two deputy governors, Charles Bean and Paul Tucker, the bank's chief economist Spencer Dale, and external members Ben Broadbent and Martin Weale.

Weale said in a speech last week that he was concerned that extra injections of funds into the banking system via QE was having little effect on direct lending to small businesses. He argued that banks were hoarding the funds to increase their reserves and meet capital requirements imposed by regulators.

Dale told MPs he agreed with this view and was encouraged that the government was backing a new scheme that rewarded banks for extra lending alongside a more relaxed credit scheme for UK banks designed to lower the cost of interbank lending. Broadbent also said he would take the new schemes into account when deciding about his vote next month.

But Miles said there was significant slack in the economy and monetary policy could still boost demand for credit.

Britain has not recovered from the 2008/2009 slump that has left many Britons worse off, and fears are rising that another prolonged recession would do lasting damage to the economy.

The pressure on the government to increase spending directly has been growing, but an unexpected increase in borrowing in May highlighted the constraints for the government, which has pledged to erase the budget deficit, which is still at around 8% of GDP.

The new funding for lending scheme – designed to lower banks' funding costs in return for more lending to companies and households by allowing them to swap illiquid assets for more liquid ones – should be up and running within weeks, King said.

webTitle: European cruise industry buoyant despite recession and Costa Concordia

fields.standfirst: Older generation who sustain Europe's cruise industry are holidaying in greater numbers with British passengers leading the way
fields.body:
The eurozone crisis may have left millions of young people jobless but the older generation who sustain Europe's cruise industry are holidaying in greater numbers – with British passengers leading the way.

Figures released by the European Cruise Council show 6.2 million people took a cruise last year, a 9% increase from 2010. The number of customers from the UK grew by 10% to 1.7 million.

Booking volumes dipped earlier this year after the Costa Concordia disaster in January, when 32 people died after the cruise ship struck rocks on the Italian coast. However, the industry says bookings have recovered.

The Costa line itself, having slashed prices to attract customers back, has seen a 25% increase in bookings compared with this time a year ago, its owner, Carnival Corporation, announced last week.

The ECC has released research claiming that cruising has generated record spending of £12.1bn annually in Europe on other businesses and employers who service the industry, such as shipbuilders, food producers, and providers of port facilities.

Its figures show the industry contributed £2.28bn to UK economic activity in 2011, where it claims to have provided employment for 63,834 people, 14,486 working directly for cruise lines.

Its research shows Southampton, the second busiest European port (after Venice) for cruises, used by 1.5 million passengers, gained economic benefits of more than £300m from the industry.

David Dingle, a member of the ECC executive and chief executive of Carnival UK, said: "Despite these challenging times the cruise industry is making an increasingly significant contribution to the British economy and that of mainland Europe by creating jobs and acting as a catalyst for tourism.

"And next year we will see more ships deployed in UK ports which we believe is testimony to the continued confidence in the UK as the world's second largest source market for the cruise industry."

webTitle: RBS glitch needs full investigation, says Mervyn King

fields.bodyText: Sir Mervyn King, governor of the Bank of England, called for a full review into what caused the computer meltdown at Royal Bank of Scotland, as the bailed-out bank admitted a "few specific sets of transactions" continue to be trapped in its computer system. King told the Treasury select committee of MPs that he had been "kept in very close touch with the very senior RBS management over the weekend". "It is still going to take time to catch up. What is important now is that we provide any support need," King said. The Financial Services Authority should, he said, carry out an investigation once the week-long situation had been resolved. RBS's chief executive, Stephen Hester, remains under pressure over the unprecedented systems meltdown which left the bank unable to update customer balances and left a defendant behind bars over the weekend after his bail money failed to arrive, while other customers face difficulties in paying bills and moving home. RBS and its NatWest subsidiary said the bulk of transactions were now being handled properly after being cleared successfully overnight but extended opening hours are in operation at both banks until the end of the week while a back log is cleared. Hester has explained the computer problem as a software upgrade that went wrong. "It is like, I don't know, the landing path at Heathrow or something, once you get out of sequences it takes some time to get back into sequence even if the original fault is put right," Hester told the BBC on Monday. RBS and NatWest said that "with the exception of a few specific sets of transactions," accounts were now being updated overnight. "We know this disruption was unacceptable and that many customers will still have questions and concerns. It is possible a small number of customers may experience delays as we return to a completely normal service. We will continue to extend our branch opening hours all week," the bank added. Its focus is now on sorting out the problems at Ulster Bank where customers are continuing to experience "unacceptable" delays to their accounts being updated. Senior RBS director Chris Sullivan has been sent to Dublin to oversee the resolution of the problem. "We are confident that this will help us restore a full service for the start of next week for Ulster Bank and remain grateful for our customers' patience. We will continue with extended opening hours for the remainder of this week and with the extensive customer support we have in place to mitigate the impact of this delay," RBS said. The bank has pledged to ensure customers do not suffer losses as a result of the computer problems and other banks are being urged by the Financial Services Authority to treat their own customers fairly if they are affected by the RBS problems. Other banks are also being caught up with the RBS problems, for instance if their employers banked with RBS. Hester has promised a "drains up" review of the debacle once the problems are solved while the FSA has said it wants a full account of what went wrong.

webTitle: RBS computer failure forces bailed defendant to spend weekend in cell

fields.standfirst: Defendant was allowed bail on Friday but not freed until Monday because it was not clear whether bail surety had been paid
fields.body:
An accused man who had been granted bail had to spend the weekend in a remand cell because of the RBS computer fiasco, it emerged on Tuesday.

The unidentified defendant was allowed bail at Canterbury crown court in Kent on Friday but was not freed until Monday because it was not clear whether his bail surety had been paid.

But a defendant in an unrelated case at Westminster magistrates court in London on the same day was freed after a judge made allowances.

The software failure at RBS and two of its subsidiaries, NatWest and Ulster Bank, has affected 17 million customers. The banks are extending opening hours all week in an attempt to clear the backlog of problems and arranged for customers to be advanced cash when they have missed payments and had no available funds.

The banks face complaints from those who have incurred extra costs because of the computer problem.

HM Courts and Tribunals Service said: "Defendants are released on bail once confirmation of the receipt of bail is received.

"We are aware of only two cases where there was a banking issue. We were advised of one case by barristers yesterday morning.

"It related to a case last Friday and court staff used their discretion to ensure that the defendant was released as soon as possible. In the second case the judge made a judicial decision last Friday to release the defendant given the circumstances."

webTitle: UK government borrowing higher than expected as income tax receipts fall

fields.standfirst: ONS figures showing borrowing of £18bn in May – up from £15bn in same month in 2011 – are blow for George Osborne
fields.body:
Britain's public finances sank deeper into the red last month as weaker tax receipts from the recession-hit economy depleted the Treasury's coffers.

Figures from the Office for National Statistics showed that net borrowing excluding financial help to Britain's banks stood at almost £18bn in May – up from just over £15bn in the same month in 2011.

City analysts had been expecting net borrowing to come in at around £14.5bn in May but the ONS said income tax receipts were down more than 7% on May 2011 while government spending was up by 8%.

The deteriorating state of the public finances is a setback for the chancellor, George Osborne, who has announced tax increases and spending cuts in an attempt to trim Britain's record peacetime budget deficit.

Rachel Reeves, Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, said they were "another nail in the coffin" of David Cameron and George Osborne's economic plan and that the government's pledge to balance the books by 2015 "is now in tatters."

She said: "As we consistently warned, if you choke off the recovery and push the economy into recession, the government ends up having to borrowing more not less."

Reeves added: "If we're to succeed in getting the deficit down we need tough decisions on tax, spending and pay but we also need a plan for jobs and growth. Unless the chancellor finally changes course and adopts a more balanced plan he will end up borrowing billions more to pay for economic failure and cause long-term damage to our economy too."

The ONS said that in the first two months of the 2012-13 financial year, net borrowing would have been £4bn higher had it not been for the one-off windfall for the Treasury from the transfer of £28bn of assets from the Post Office pension fund.

In a further blow to the chancellor, the ONS said changes to the way it calculates the public finances had resulted in the deficit for 2011-12 being revised up by £3.2bn to £127.6bn.

City analysts said the figures cast doubt on forecasts from the independent Office for Budget Responsibility that borrowing in 2012-13 would be around £93bn.

James Knightley, an economist at ING bank, said: "It appears that the main problem was with income tax receipts, which were down 7.3% year on year in April/May on the same period last year. Meanwhile, the effectiveness of government austerity measures again comes into question with spending actually rising – note also that government spending has been the main growth contributor to GDP since the start of the financial crisis.

"We continue to see upside risk for UK government borrowing given the disappointing activity data and very weak wage growth, which we suspect will necessitate upward revisions to official government debt and borrowing forecasts."

Vicky Redwood, UK analyst at Capital Economic, said: "After the transfer of the Royal Mail pension fund temporarily flattered the UK public finances in April, it was back to "deficits as normal" in May.

"The main problem remains a sharp slowdown in tax receipts. And with the economy probably still in recession, receipts are likely to remain weak. The combination of worsening public finances and renewed recession is likely to intensify calls for the government to change tack on its austerity programme."

webTitle: BP moves higher after selling North Sea assets to Japan's Mitsui

fields.standfirst: Oil giant's disposal programme continues, while economic woes send FTSE 100 back into the red
fields.body:
BP's disposal programme continues apace, with the sale of some of its North Sea assets to Japan's Mitsui.

It has agreed to dispose of its 13.3% stake in the Alba field and 8.97% of Britannia for €280m in cash. BP director Trevor Garlick said:

The divestments are part of our strategy to develop a more focussed business in the UK and Norway.

The move comes a day after BP sold $1bn worth of US gas assets to Linn Energy, and the disposal of $400m worth of North Sea gas business earlier in the year. This is all part of its $38bn disposal programme to raise funds to pay the costs of 2010's Gulf of Mexico oil spill disaster.

BP has also said it could sell its stake in Russian oil joint venture TNK-BP up for sale.

BP shares have added 4.35p to 406.4p, but the market has come off its best levels, not helped by downbeat comments from Bank of England governor Sir Mervyn King and worst than expected UK public finance figures. The FTSE 100 is now down 5.48 points at 5445.17.

Elsewhere Carpetright has climbed 35p to 688.5p after its figures came in no worse than expected, following a series of profit warnings. Full year underlying profits dropped 76% to £4m.

Transport group Stagecoach is up 12.9p at 262.7p despite a disappointing performance from its UK rail business.

But online grocer Ocado dropped 17.1p to 91p, or nearly 16%. The company said half year pretax profit was £200,000, its debt had climbed to £71.3m and it said there had been some disruption from the Jubilee celebrations and it was uncertain about the effect of the Olympics.

webTitle: Leaders draft federal plan to save the eurozone

fields.standfirst: Four European presidents make proposals to ramp up the powers of eurozone authorities over national governments
fields.body:
European leaders have drafted a radical plan to turn the 17 countries of the eurozone into a full-fledged political federation within a decade in an attempt to placate the financial markets by demonstrating a political will to save the single currency in the medium-term.

The incendiary proposals for banking, fiscal, and economic unions resulting in a "political union" are to be debated at an EU summit on Thursday and Friday. Following two bad-tempered meetings of European leaders in Mexico and Rome over the past week, the Brussels summit looks likely to see major clashes over the future of Europe as well as the immediate crisis surrounding sovereign debt, bad banks and the euro's survival.

The crisis has shifted from the periphery of the EU to its very heart, with Berlin and Paris seriously at odds for the first time since the Greek drama started 30 months ago. The logic of the draft proposals will also pose major dilemmas for David Cameron, perhaps putting Britain at a crossroads in its relationship with the continent.

The seven-page document, obtained by the Guardian, has been drafted by the "gang of four" – a quartet of European presidents: Herman Van Rompuy of the European Council, Mario Draghi of the European Central Bank, José Manuel Barroso of the European commission, and Jean-Claude Juncker of the 17-country eurogroup.

It calls for a quick start on establishing a new European banking union, says that the ECB could be given supervisory authority over EU banks quickly, and proposes common resolution funds (for winding up bad banks, funded by a banking levy to spare EU taxpayers) as well as a common deposit guarantee scheme for Europe's savers.

Berlin is already pooh-poohing the notion, unwilling to "mutualise" liability for other country's savers or banks any time soon. The paper also says that the eurozone's new permanent bailout fund, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), could be used as the "fiscal backstop" for a banking union, opening the way to direct recapitalisation of troubled banks, also opposed by the key power, Germany.

Britain is adamantly opposed to joining a banking union and placing much of Europe's biggest financial centre, the City, under the authority of the ECB. Arguing that the union should be purely eurozone as a response to the euro crisis, Cameron will demand "safeguards" quarantining the British financial sector while ensuring that any new financial regime does not impair Britian's interests in the EU's single market.

The Germans appear reluctant to offer any concessions, though, and the draft says the banking union should extend beyond the eurozone.

"An integrated financial framework should cover all EU member states, whilst allowing for specific differentiations between euro and non-euro area member states on certain parts of the new framework that are preponderantly linked to the functioning of the monetary union and the stability of the euro area rather than to the single market."

Analysts say that a banking union cannot work without a eurozone fiscal union and the paper proposes sweeping new eurozone powers, including options, fiercely resisted by Berlin, for sharing liability for the debt of eurozone countries – eurobonds. The paper seeks to accommodate German objections by bowing to chancellor Angela Merkel's new mantra – "no liability without controls".

"In a medium term perspective, the issuance of common debt could be explored as an element of such a fiscal union and subject to progress on fiscal integration. Steps towards the introduction of joint and several sovereign liabilities could be considered as long as a robust framework for budgetary discipline and competitiveness is in place to avoid moral hazard," the paper says.

"Progress in the pooling of decisions on budgets would be accompanied with commensurate steps towards the pooling of risks. Several options for partial common debt issuance have been proposed, such as the pooling of some short-term funding instruments on a limited and conditional basis, or the gradual roll-over into a redemption fund. Different forms of fiscal solidarity could also be envisaged."

Full fiscal union, the paper says, will ultimately require what is tantamount to a eurozone finance ministry – "the development at the euro area level of a fiscal body, such as a treasury office".

On budgetary and economic policy-making, the proposals ramp up the powers of EU or eurozone authorities to dictate and enforce national decision-taking, for example, on labour markets or "tax co-ordination".

It also suggests that European authorities could intervene to ensure national civil service and other reforms, as is currently being tried as part of the Greek bailout.

"Measures to strengthen the political and administrative capacity of national institutions and foster national ownership of reforms could be taken where necessary, as this is a vital condition for the efficient implementation of growth-enhancing reforms."

The gang of four paper calls for much more intrusive eurozone powers over national budgets, fiscal and economic policy-making.

"Upper limits on the annual budget balance and on government debt levels of individual member states could be agreed in common. Under these rules, the issuance of government debt beyond the level agreed in common would have to be justified and receive prior approval. Subsequently, the euro area level would be in a position to require changes to budgetary envelopes if they are in violation of fiscal rules."

The four presidents ask for a mandate from this week's summit to draw up "a specific and time-bound road map for the achievement of genuine Economic and Monetary Union", stating they should deliver an interim report in October and more detailed plans by the end of the year.

There are certain to be major conflicts over the proposals before that happens. The likelihood is that the banking union can be established without having to resort to the hazardous step of re-opening the EU's Lisbon Treaty. But the other ambitions would require reopening the EU's decade-old quandary over a European constitution.

France will be deeply reluctant to surrender so much sovereign powers to new eurozone authorities, while Germany will only accept liability for others if the powers are federalised.

Amid deepseated Franco-German divisions, Merkel is to go to Paris on the eve of Thursday's summit to try to strike a deal with French president François Hollande.

The Wednesday evening dinner is being preceded today by talks in Paris between the German, French, Spanish, and Italian finance ministers.

For the master plan to work, Germany would also need a new Basic Law or constitution, as suggested at the weekend by Wolfgang Schäuble, the finance minister.

Hollande would have a hard time delivering a socialist party still deeply divided on Europe ever since the French voted against a European constitution in 2005. Hollande's foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, spearheaded the No campaign.

webTitle: FTSE regains some ground but outsourcer Serco slides after cutting revenue expectations

fields.standfirst: Company behind prisons and air traffic control centres more downbeat on first half performance
fields.body:
Markets have recovered some ground after Monday's fall, but outsourcing group Serco has missed out after a downbeat trading update.

The company, which runs prisons, the London Docklands light railway and air traffic control centres, said in a trading update that it expected a small fall in revenues in the first half. Previously it had indicated flat revenues. The new statement prompted analysts to suggest a possible decline of around 2% in revenues.

It blamed tough conditions in America although it was seeing an improvement in the UK. It said its overall performance would be weighted to the second half.

That caution was enough to send its shares 14p lower to 526p, a 2.5% decline. David Brockton at Espirito Santo said:

In its traditionally short first half pre-close update Serco reconfirms its guidance for 2012, but signals slightly worse than expected performance through the first half. While we expect to make no material change to our forecasts, the balance of risk would appear to remain to the downside and we maintain our neutral rating.
Serco's breadth of service and geographic spread (c.40% of revenues international) has continued to underpin good organic growth and margin progression over the past few years, outperforming almost all outsourcing peers. Nevertheless US pressures are now prevalent, constraining growth and there is low visibility over a recovery in spend, which is key for us to turn positive.

Robin Speakman at Shore Capital said:

Serco continues to signal a year of distinctly two halves. [We believe] earnings per share is set to decline by up to 20% on the first half of 2011 to around 15.0p (our previous expectation was a decline of around 16%). As guided by Serco, we expect a strong second half performance to follow, led by a lower cost base and the noted contractual success seen through the first half. In this context, we believe that our full year forecasts remain achievable, but we will review post our call with the company tomorrow. Looking further out into 2013 and 2014 we believe that prospects continue to brighten, supporting our buy stance.

Another big faller is Royal Bank of Scotland, down 3.9p to 232.9p following the major problems with its NatWest computer failure.

But overall the FTSE 100 has so far added 11.80 points to 5462.45, helped by mining shares. But the mood is still cautious ahead of the key EU summit at the end of the week, where expectation of any major solution to the crisis are fading.

Croda has climbed 47p to £21.72 after JP Morgan Cazenove raised its rating on the chemicals company from neutral to overweight. It said:

Croda's notable characteristic through the last downturn was one of resilience, and we see no evidence to suggest that this attraction is likely to wane. The consistent emphasis on new product innovation, and the secular desire to look younger, provide new momentum, and a hedge for investors worried about the broader outlook. The company's targeted 10% growth through the cycle, while participating in high margins, product innovation and growth markets, should reassure investors.

After Monday's falls on news of sooner than expected generic competition to its key hyperactivity treatment Adderall, Shire has recovered 28p to £17.71.

Credit Suisse repeated its outperform rating but cut its target price from £23.50 to £20:

We believe [Monday's 11% share price fall] is an overreaction given there are quota limits to stimulant sales and we do not expect [rival] Actavis to have been given sufficient quota to eliminate Shire and its authorised generics from the market. Although the precise timing of approval is unexpected we have been modeling "true" generics from mid-2013.
